---
title: 'Bivariate Visualization'
---

::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_69a7e94a2f2045d14780ecd23a174978'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
```
:::



Exercise 0: 

::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_ff1e5b500888748660fdff258e2aa6a3'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Load data
elections <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_county.csv")

# Check it out
head(elections)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  state_name state_abbr historical    county_name county_fips total_votes_20
1    Alabama         AL        red Autauga County        1001          27770
2    Alabama         AL        red Baldwin County        1003         109679
3    Alabama         AL        red Barbour County        1005          10518

5    Alabama         AL        red  Blount County        1009          27588
6    Alabama         AL        red Bullock County        1011           4613

1        71.44      27.02     repub          24661        73.44      23.96

5     repub          23980        86.49      12.35     repub            57623

1            76            18             1                2             24571

```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_9c443404c7282d388e72b8b70328fedc'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(x=winner_20))+
  geom_bar()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
elections %>%
  count(winner_20)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  winner_20    n
1       dem  536
2     repub 2573
```
:::
:::

The republicans won about 82.8% of the counties. 


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_a7ae09ea7d1222fa5d1f076b29718852'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(x=repub_pct_20))+
  geom_histogram()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

I don't understand the significance of this being negatively skewed. 


Exercise 1: 

::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_dfca9806959232779b75b1711f28c195'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(x=repub_pct_16, y=repub_pct_20))+ 
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

 
Exercise 2: 


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_534310d58d9a3b641a9d23a004e86dc1'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# This shows the same plot as above in exercise 2, but with crosses. 
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point(color = 'orange', shape=3)+
  geom_text(aes(label = state_abbr))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


Exercise 3: 

With an increase in republican percentage in 2016, there is an increase in republican percentage in 2020. This relationship is very strong, and it is a positive relationship. A lot of counties in texas seem to lie above the trend (positive residuals), which could be because they are more republican than the average state. 

Exercise 4: 

::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_d9c9d6740a88cb2158a316fd1183ca0a'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'gam' and formula = 'y ~ s(x, bs = "cs")'
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_903c20fcda1145b030719d7d4ea1cde4'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_e8147511afd021e9cc94445997d4f405'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Scatterplot of repub_pct_20 vs median_rent
ggplot(elections, aes(x = median_rent, y = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_point() 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Scatterplot of repub_pct_20 vs median_age
ggplot(elections, aes(x = median_age, y = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_point() 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-2.png){width=672}
:::
:::


Median rent seems to explain repub_pct_20 better: as median rent rises, repub_pct_20 seems to fall, suggesting a moderate negative relationship. Median age does not seem to explain repub_pct_20 very well. 

Exercise 6: 


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_b64520c92d7362608788f7bdd52f7868'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

A scatterplot is very useful for 2 quantitative variables. Historical seems to be a categorical variable with 3 categories, so a boxplot would be a better idea. 

Exercise 7: 


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-11_e3461f39bf7734285a5ba8edb0a246d0'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) +
  geom_violin()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-12_f2c972023e7a9f7dcaadd42fb63eb17e'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

This tells us that if a county was historically democrat, people voted less republican in 2020 than if the country was historically purple, which is less than if the county was historically red. 

Exercise 8: 


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-13_0d4961a5f91f6ec560da40f3284f1f2f'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill=historical)) +
  geom_density(alpha=0.5)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


Exercise 9: 


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-14_3e2c980ffe91f9f2dd95a6e68a3af0cf'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Name two "bad" things about this plot
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) +
  geom_density()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

1. It is opaque, so I can't see part of the data (for the green and red plots). 
2. The colors do not correspond to the colors they are representing (red is blue, blue is red)


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-15_63b972400a38a8155a21ab2495adc391'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# What does scale_fill_manual do?
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) +
  geom_density() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", "purple", "red"))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

This fixes the second issue with this! The colors correspond to the category they are representing. 


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-16_3b2dd502a7b7da53d61321e88ea11660'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# What does alpha = 0.5 do?
# Play around with different values of alpha, between 0 and 1
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.5) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", "purple", "red"))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

This fixes the first issue I had with the plot! It increases its transparency. 


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-17_acd971ab790f54e7a9bf1e892b2175e7'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# What does facet_wrap do?!
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) +
  geom_density() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", "purple", "red")) +
  facet_wrap(~ historical)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

It makes each of the categories into separate small graphs, while using the same axes. 


::: {.cell hash='bivariate_viz_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-18_64842d5c04e4a0f3c277eaf8dc2e36d7'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Let's try a similar grouping strategy with a histogram instead of density plot.
# Why is this terrible?
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", "purple", "red"))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](bivariate_viz_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

This uses a histogram, which is difficult to understand because there is so much information!

Exercise 10: 

- Which do you like best?
Side-by-side boxplots
- What is one pro of density plots relative to boxplots?
It gives you a visual representation of how skewed the data is
- What is one con of density plots relative to boxplots?
It does not give you any numerical summaries (IQR, median)
